newsitem.title: USA: U.S. may speed troop withdrawal from Bosnia.
newsitem.headline: U.S. may speed troop withdrawal from Bosnia.

text.p: The United States said on Tuesday it might speed withdrawal of 15,000 U.S. peacekeeping troops from Bosnia because of a delay in holding municipal elections there until next year.

It also said Bosnian Serbs were "on probation" and could lose international aid or face new sanctions if they did not cooperate with the Organisation for European Security and Cooperation (OSCE) on the polls, expected by June.
"It is possible that there could be some acceleration in the redeployment" in the American troops in Bosnia, Pentagon spokesman Ken Bacon told reporters.
But he stressed that current plans to have most of those troops out early next year remained in effect.
President Bill Clinton promised to have U.S. troops out of Bosnia by Dec. 20, but that deadline has already slipped.

Talk of extending their stay -- or deploying a new force -- drew fire from critics who feared an open-ended American commitment in the Balkans. This has been an issue in the U.S. presidential election.

U.S. Gen. George Joulwan, NATO's supreme allied commander, had said most of the 50,000-member NATO-led peace implementation force (IFOR) in Bosnia, including 15,000 Americans, needed to remain to ensure security for the municipal elections when they were planned for November.
With the polls postponed, a speedier withdrawal was possible. But this also could mean a follow-on force would be even more necessary to provide security when the elections do take place.

Bacon spoke shortly after the head of the international mission organising Bosnia's postwar elections, American Robert Frowick, announced that municipal voting set for November would be postponed because of "continuing political problems."

Bacon said he did not know exactly how the move would affect IFOR. The delay was a factor in whether the United States and its allies send a "follow-on" peacekeeping force to Bosnia next year, but no decision had been made, he said.
"I'm saying that as of right now ... our plans are unchanged and the IFOR forces are coming out. I anticipate they will come out on schedule, possibly ahead of schedule," Bacon said.
The U.S. State Department backed the OSCE postponement decision but said elections must ultimately be held under OSCE auspices and Bosnia Serbs must cooperate or face consequences.

"There's no question ... that one of the great problems encountered in arranging the elections in November was the unwillingness of the Bosnian Serbs to cooperate with the OSCE," spokesman Nicholas Burns said.

"The Bosnian Serb leadership should understand that the ability and the willingness of the international community to be helpful to them economically and otherwise is a direct function of their cooperation on this issue," he said.
The Serbs are "on probation" and could face re-imposition of sanctions, he added.

The United States had insisted Bosnia's national elections be held in September despite deep concerns in many quarters that conditions in Bosnia -- including little freedom of movement -- would not permit free and fair polls.
Burns insisted the municipal elections were different. The 1995 Bosnia peace accord mandated national elections but said municipal polls should be held "if feasible."
